Notes: Meta/Facebook engineering research showing AV1 uses 46% less bandwidth than H.264, the most commonly used codec on web
4K photo = 8,294,400 bytes (3 bytes per pixel for RGB). 30fps video would be ~15GB per minute uncompressed
Modern codecs compress video to 1% of original size with minimal perceptible quality loss
Google Pixel 6 includes hardware-accelerated AV1 decoding in Tensor chip, uses minimal battery/CPU
Samsung Exynos 2200 chipset supports hardware-accelerated AV1 decoding
MediaTek Dimensity 1000 SoC supports hardware-accelerated AV1 decoding
Google appears to require all Android 14 devices support AV1 decoding (referenced with CTS commit)
AVPlayer (iOS/tvOS media API) includes kcmvideocodectype_av1 option, hints at future support
Single core AMD EPYC 7642 took 30+ minutes to encode 2 seconds of 4K@30fps using libaom-av1
Live encoding with CPUs only would require 20+ servers at full capacity even with 48-core processors
VR headsets support 5760x3840 resolution = 22.1 million pixels per frame
4K displays = 8.8 million pixels per frame
Professional 4K ProRes video consumes approximately 6GB per minute of footage
Author found 150kb/s optimal for VTuber streams with mostly static overlays and text content, 720p@30fps
Final optimized encoding: 89MB/hour for VTuber streams using H.264 with libfdk_aac audio @ 32kb/s
Using libfdk_aac with HE-AACv2 profile at 32kb/s for speech-optimized audio in streams
Music/gameplay videos require 64kb/s AAC to maintain quality (vs 32kb/s for speech)
AV1 is open source and royalty-free, backed by Alliance for Open Media with major tech companies
Optimized HLS chunks approximately same size as 1-1.5 JPEG images for efficient delivery
AMD EPYC 7642 48-core processor with 256GB RAM used as workhorse for Cloudflare's encoding tests
